notes: Templates are caregiver-oriented, non-diagnostic, and uncertainty-aware.
Texts are grounded on inferred patterns + supplement features (EWI, dwell, crossings, speech activity, masking score).
Use as a prototype narration library for Step 1; later can be expanded or used for LoRA fine-tuning of a small LM.

style_rules: Do not diagnose or label the child.
Explain what the system sees, why it matters, what to try now, and what may happen next.
If confidence is low, say so and avoid strong recommendations.

messages: The signals are mixed, so I am not sure what is happening right now. I may be missing important context.
If you know what changed in the environment (noise, light, schedule, a small rule breaking), your judgement is more reliable than this tool.
If distress increases, try a calm pause and reduce stimulation. If things improve, continue with a steady routine.
Your child may look calm, but some signals suggest tension underneath. This can happen when stress is hidden or 'masked.'
A gentle check-in can help: stay close, speak softly, and offer one simple choice. Avoid sudden demands while the tension is high.

high: Stress seems to be building up. Small supports now can prevent a bigger reaction later.
If possible, lower the stimulation (reduce noise, bright light, or fast talking) and give a short break.
medium: There are mild signs of rising stress. Keeping things predictable may help.
If you notice repeated small worries, consider slowing down and offering clearer next steps.
low: Stress signals look low right now. A steady routine is usually enough.
If a worry appears again, support early rather than waiting for escalation.

messages: He stayed in a tense state for about {distress_dwell_sec} seconds, with {crossings} escalation crossings. This matters because repeated crossings can lead to exhaustion or a sudden meltdown later.

high: There is active speech/voicing. This often means he is trying to communicate needs, even if the words are short or repetitive.
Try reflecting back in simple language: 'You want to start together' or 'You want it fixed,' and then offer a clear next step.
medium: There is some voicing. He may be testing whether you understand what he wants.
Short, calm responses and one clear option can reduce frustration.
low: There is little speech/voicing. He may be overwhelmed, tired, or shutting down.
Give space, reduce stimulation, and avoid pushing for explanations in the moment.

share_control.description: Need for shared timing, joint start, or matched control. Distress rises when sequence/timing breaks.
templates: Main pattern: share-control (confidence {confidence:.2f}). Your child may want to begin together or match timing with you.
When the sequence changes unexpectedly, distress can rise quickly because the shared plan feels broken.
{early_warning_block}
{speech_activity_block}
What to try now: reset the start together. Use a simple phrase like 'together, one-two-three' and begin at the same time.
What may happen next: if the timing breaks again, distress may increase; if you restart together, he often returns to calm faster.
Main pattern: share-control (confidence {confidence:.2f}). This looks like a 'start together' situation.
Even small differences (you wash first, you open the toy first) can feel like losing shared control.
{early_warning_block}
What to try now: pause, acknowledge his request, and offer a synchronized restart. Keep your voice slow and steady.
If the support works, the worry should drop within a short window. If not, he may move toward crying or shutting down.

repair_integrity.description: Integrity-violation response: something feels wrong/broken and the child needs it restored to feel safe.
templates: Main pattern: repair-integrity (confidence {confidence:.2f}). Something may feel 'wrong' or not complete to your child.
This is not just a preference. For some children, a small break (a torn cover, a missing piece) can feel like a safety problem.
{early_warning_block}
{speech_activity_block}
What to try now: if safe, repair the object or restore the rule. If you cannot, offer a substitute repair: cover it, put it away, or create a clear 'finished' boundary.
What may happen next: if the integrity issue stays unresolved, distress may persist; if you can repair or close the loop, calm often returns.
Main pattern: repair-integrity (confidence {confidence:.2f}). He may be asking for the world to feel 'whole' again.
You might see repeated requests, checking behavior, or insistence that you undo a change.
{early_warning_block}
What to try now: validate first ('It feels wrong'). Then give one simple plan: 'We can't fix this, but we can put it away safely.'
If the plan is clear and consistent, the reaction often softens. If plans change repeatedly, distress can rise.

delayed_meltdown.description: Stress accumulates quietly (often behind calm/neutral expression) then breaks into crying or shutdown.
templates: Main pattern: delayed-meltdown (confidence {confidence:.2f}). Your child may look calm at first, but stress can build quietly inside.
This matters because the visible reaction can appear suddenly, even if the earlier cues were small.
{early_warning_block}
{dwell_crossings_block}
What to try now: reduce stimulation and lower demands. Offer a calm break and a simple choice (water, hug, quiet corner).
What may happen next: if stress continues, crying or shutdown may follow. If support happens early, he may return to calm without a big episode.
Main pattern: delayed-meltdown (confidence {confidence:.2f}). The system sees a build-up pattern rather than a single sudden trigger.
Sometimes children hold it together until one more small change pushes them over the edge.
{early_warning_block}
What to try now: slow down transitions, avoid extra instructions, and keep the environment predictable for a few minutes.
If you see repeated small spikes, treat them as early warnings. Preventing escalation is usually easier than stopping a meltdown mid-way.

mask_snap.description: Positive/neutral-looking expression followed by abrupt distress; often described as masking then snapping.
templates: Main pattern: mask-snap (confidence {confidence:.2f}). Your child may appear okay, then suddenly move into distress.
This can happen when stress is hidden for a while and then 'snaps' once capacity is exceeded.
{early_warning_block}
{speech_activity_block}
What to try now: treat the early tension as real even if the face looks calm. Offer a short break and reduce stimulation.
What may happen next: if demands continue, distress may escalate quickly. If you pause and support early, the snap may be avoided.
Main pattern: mask-snap (confidence {confidence:.2f}). The signals suggest a fast switch from controlled behavior to crying or shutdown.
This is not manipulation. It often reflects a narrow coping window.
{early_warning_block}
What to try now: use fewer words, move slowly, and provide one clear safe option (quiet space, predictable routine).
If the coping window is exceeded again soon, another snap can happen. If you protect the window, recovery is faster.

frozen_distress.description: Low expression, stillness, quiet voice; can indicate shutdown/overload rather than calm.
templates: Main pattern: frozen-distress (confidence {confidence:.2f}). Your child is very still and shows little expression.
This may not mean calm. It can be a shutdown response to overload or fear.
{early_warning_block}
{speech_activity_block}
What to try now: give space and reduce stimulation. Avoid rapid questions. Stay nearby so he feels safe without pressure.
What may happen next: after shutdown, some children cry later or become exhausted. Gentle recovery is often better than pushing to 'talk it out.'
Main pattern: frozen-distress (confidence {confidence:.2f}). The system sees low outward expression with internal tension cues.
Think of it as 'freeze' rather than 'fine.'
What to try now: lower demands, keep routines simple, and allow quiet time. Offer help with one short sentence at a time.
If stimulation increases, the freeze can turn into crying. If the environment stays calm, he may slowly return to normal activity.

sensory_overload.description: Escalation driven by sensory load (noise/light/touch/crowd); often leads to crying then shutdown.
templates: Main pattern: sensory-overload (confidence {confidence:.2f}). The system suggests the environment may be overwhelming.
Noise, light, touch, or fast social input can push a child from calm into fear and crying quickly.
{early_warning_block}
{dwell_crossings_block}
What to try now: reduce sensory input (quiet, dim light, fewer people). Use a calm voice and give a clear escape option.
What may happen next: if overload continues, crying or shutdown may follow. If the environment is softened, recovery is more likely.
Main pattern: sensory-overload (confidence {confidence:.2f}). This looks less like 'bad behavior' and more like too much input.
{early_warning_block}
What to try now: move to a quieter place, reduce talking, and allow self-soothing (cover ears, hold an object, rocking).
If the load drops, worry should decrease. If not, distress may keep rising.

ocd_loop.description: Persistent worry-like state with low escape; repeated checking or insistence may appear.
templates: Main pattern: ocd-loop (confidence {confidence:.2f}). Your child may be stuck in a worry loop for a long time.
This can look like repeated checking, repeated questions, or difficulty moving on even when you reassure him.
{early_warning_block}
{speech_activity_block}
What to try now: give one clear reassurance and one clear plan. Too many different explanations can make the loop stronger.
What may happen next: if the loop is interrupted gently with a stable routine, tension can reduce. If the routine keeps changing, worry may persist.
Main pattern: ocd-loop (confidence {confidence:.2f}). The system sees long, steady worry without a clear drop back to calm.
This suggests he may need closure or a predictable 'end' signal.
What to try now: use a consistent closing phrase ('All done, safe now') and a consistent action (put away, checklist, timer).
If closure is repeated consistently, the loop often weakens over days. If closure changes each time, the loop can stay strong.

calm_worry_calm: He became briefly worried but returned to calm on his own. This suggests a small stress that he was able to handle.
No action is needed now, but staying nearby and keeping the environment steady may help.
If similar worries happen more often or last longer, stress may build up and lead to distress later.
calm_worry_worry: He moved from calm into worry and stayed there. This may mean stress is slowly building.
Reducing noise or giving one clear next step may help prevent escalation.
If the worry continues without support, crying or shutdown may follow.
worry_cry_blank: Worry rose into crying, then he became quiet and still. This can be an overload-to-shutdown pattern.
Give space and reduce stimulation. Avoid many questions in the moment.
When he recovers, keep the next steps simple and predictable.
